content.title: Persistent Sciatic Artery (PSA)
content.definition: Rare congenital vascular anomaly in which the embryonic sciatic artery fails to regress, persisting as the dominant arterial supply to the lower extremity, exiting the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen with the sciatic nerve. Associated with aneurysm formation and limb ischemia.

key_concepts.description: Sciatic artery is the original blood supply to the leg bud in embryonic development; normally involutes as the femoral system develops. Persistence represents failure of normal regression
Complete PSA: sciatic artery provides dominant lower extremity supply, SFA absent or hypoplastic. Incomplete PSA: both sciatic and femoral systems present
Arises from internal iliac artery; exits pelvis through greater sciatic foramen with sciatic nerve; continues along posterior thigh as popliteal artery
High propensity for aneurysm formation (40-50% of cases); vulnerable to repetitive trauma from sitting (ischial tuberosity compression); aneurysms prone to thrombosis and embolization
May present with buttock mass (aneurysm); acute limb ischemia from thrombosis/embolization; chronic ischemia; may be incidental finding; sciatic neuropathy from nerve compression
Absent or weak femoral pulse with palpable popliteal pulse (unusual pattern); pulsatile gluteal mass; presence of gluteal bruit; Cowie sign (pulsatile mass in buttock)
CTA/MRA shows anomalous arterial course through greater sciatic foramen; angiography confirms; important to identify before hip surgery or sciatic nerve blocks
Asymptomatic without aneurysm: observation. Aneurysm: exclusion with bypass (femoropopliteal bypass using vein graft); endovascular options in selected cases
Bilateral in 30-40% of cases; always image contralateral side if found
Popliteal aneurysm, gluteal artery aneurysm, soft tissue tumor, sciatic nerve tumor

signs: Weak/absent femoral pulse with palpable popliteal

learning_objectives: Define persistent sciatic artery and its embryology
Recognize the characteristic physical finding (weak femoral, normal popliteal)
Know to image contralateral side (30-40% bilateral)
clinical_pearls: Absent femoral pulse + present popliteal = suspect PSA
Relevant before hip surgery or sciatic nerve blocks
Rare but important board question topic
common_mistakes: Attempting standard femoropopliteal bypass (must use different inflow)
Missing during workup for hip surgery (can be injured)
